text_image_relationship.layout_style: Full‐page illustration occupying majority of the folio above a single line of text at the foot. Wide margins on all sides filled with delicate vine scrolls and foliate motifs. No text interlaces the image; image stands alone in a rectangular Gothic architectural frame with pinnacles and battlements.

text_content.script_style: Gothic textura quadrata with red rubrication and fine pen flourishes

color_scheme.color_usage: Gold leaf reserved for architectural framing and hierarchically important figures. Ultramarine establishes the clerical robes and sky‐like backgrounds, while vermilion highlights princely and knightly garments. White lead used for highlighting drapery folds and facial modeling. The limited palette alternates red and blue to organize figures and creates a visual rhythm in the lower register with contrasting water tones and architectural columns.

features: Two‐tiered register with main investiture scene above subsidiary interior and river scene
Symmetrical Gothic frame emphasises central action
Hierarchical scaling: bishop at center largest, attendants slightly smaller
Overlapping figures to suggest shallow depth
Repetitive architectural arches divide and unify scenes

decorative_elements: Gothic micro‐architectural frame with pinnacles and crocketed finials
Gold diapered background within the upper hall
Interlaced vine scroll marginalia with acanthus leaves
Diaper pattern of quatrefoils on lower border

drawing_technique.line_style: Fluid quill pen outlines with varying weight; fine internal detailing in faces and drapery
drawing_technique.shading_method: Parallel hatching and cross-hatching in drapery folds with layered pigments and white highlights
drawing_technique.perspective_handling: Hierarchical scaling without vanishing‐point perspective; depth indicated by overlapping and tiered registers

scene_relationships.subject: Investiture of a ruler by a bishop in a Gothic hall
scene_relationships.relationship_to_next: Leads to depiction of monastic and funerary aftermath below, implying spiritual outcome of sacred investiture
visual_connections: Red and blue palette repeated in both registers
Vine scroll motif continues between registers
Patterned floor tiling echoed in lower pavement

scene_relationships.subject: Interior monastic cells and a funerary barge on a river
scene_relationships.relationship_to_next: Concludes narrative by showing spiritual journey and monastic discipline resulting from the investiture
visual_connections: Continuation of battlemented facade from upper scene
Blue water echoes blue robes above
Gold highlights on furniture match upper gold diaper
Arched cell frames mirror hall arches

visual_continuity: Vine scroll marginalia unifying image and margins

content_theme.scene_description: Primary Scene Analysis: Seven figures occupy the top register. At center stands a bishop in a cloth-of-gold mitre and pink cope, his left hand holding a jewelled crozier and his right raised in blessing. Before him kneels a ruler in blue tunic and red mantle, bareheaded and on one knee on a black-and-white tiled floor. Behind the bishop three clerics in alternating ultramarine and vermilion copes stand in graduated hierarchy, two with hands clasped and one gesturing toward the kneeling figure. To the far right a knight in chainmail and red surcoat holds a scroll-banner inscribed in Latin. The hall features a coffered red ceiling with gold bosses, slender columns and a gold diapered background. Spatial Organization: Central figures occupy shallow pictorial space, their overlapping forms creating depth. The bishop is hierarchically largest. Costume and Equipment Details: The bishop’s mitre is in cloth-of-gold with punchwork, his crozier gilded with pearl inlays. The kneeling ruler’s mantle is woolen with a bronze clasp. Clerics’ copes are damask patterned. The knight’s mail hauberk and surcoat bear no heraldic device but convey martial status. Secondary Elements: The Gothic frame with pinnacles extends vertical emphasis. Border vine scrolls carry acanthus leaves and tiny buds. Decorative quatrefoil diaper appears behind the scene and on the lower border. Symbolic Components: The crozier and mitre identify ecclesiastical authority; the kneeling posture signifies submission to divine sanction. The battlements link secular power to fortress imagery. Visual-Textual Relationships: The single Latin rubric at foot refers to investiture and complementing visual narrative. The clear separation of text and image emphasizes the image’s standalone expository role.

religious: Bishop in cloth-of-gold mitre and cope
Three clerics in ultramarine and vermilion copes
secular: Kneeling ruler in blue tunic and red mantle
Knight in chainmail with red surcoat

architectural: Gothic micro-architecture frame with battlements and pinnacles

technical_features.material: Premium calfskin vellum, evenly scraped and pumiced, pricked and ruled with visible hair follicle pattern
technical_features.preservation_condition: Vivid pigments with minimal oxidation; slight flaking of vermilion in upper register; minor cockling in margins; gold leaf remains largely intact
notable_physical_characteristics: Raised gesso under gold leaf in diaper backgrounds
Regular plummet ruling lines in margins

analysis.scholarly_interpretation: This folio likely originates from a mid-14th-century court workshop in northern France, reflecting the heightened interest in sacral investiture narratives during the reign of Philip VI. The lavish use of ultramarine and gold leaf, combined with the refined Gothic architectural framing, aligns with the ornamental tastes of high aristocracy and suggests commission by a noble patron seeking to legitimize authority through divine sanction. Stylistically, the painting demonstrates the influence of the Parisian illuminator Jean Pucelle, especially in the delicate vine scroll marginalia and the crisply modelled drapery ornamented with white lead highlights. The collaborative nature of the work is evident in the differing brushwork between the richly patterned copes and the more restrained lower register—a two‐handed atelier practice typical of court workshops. Iconographically, the investiture scene asserts the sacral origins of temporal power, while the lower register’s monastic and funerary imagery reinforces the moral imperative of spiritual vigilance. Politically, the image serves as a visual assertion of royal or noble legitimacy by equating secular rule with ecclesiastical endorsement. Compared with other manuscripts such as the Psalter of Jeanne de Navarre, this illumination combines traditional hierarchical scaling with a novel two-tiered narrative structure, bridging established iconographic conventions with innovative compositional strategies.
